tech_stack: Go-Ethereum derivative (inferred from MEV builder architecture)

technical_details.description: Middleware solution that divides 12-second Ethereum blocks into twelve 1-second mini-rounds with sealed-bid auctions
technical_details.funding: $6M seed round (Cyber Fund, Maven11, DCG, Greenfield Capital, Eden Block)

gaps_identified.description: No public GitHub repository found for NuConstruct
gaps_identified.evidence: Extensive searches on GitHub using multiple query patterns returned no results. NuConstruct appears to operate as a proprietary MEV builder with closed-source code.

gaps_identified.description: MEV bot contract 0x3face0004bc1003b9d0672e7b23134cb80115fb6 is not verified on Etherscan
gaps_identified.evidence: Etherscan page shows active MEV bot but no verified source code available

gaps_identified.description: Programming languages and frameworks are inferred from MEV builder architecture patterns, not directly documented
gaps_identified.evidence: Tech stack inferred from: (1) MEV builder operations typically use Go-Ethereum derivatives, (2) Smart contracts on Ethereum use Solidity, (3) Intel TDX confirmed from multiple news sources

data_sources.data_extracted: Platform overview, supported networks, contact information
TOOL platform technical details, Intel TDX usage, block subdivision mechanism
Collaboration with Flashbots, TDX experimentation, 0x3face bot identification
MEV bot contract address, transaction patterns
Company description, founding date, funding information

research_notes: NuConstruct is a proprietary MEV infrastructure company, not an open-source privacy project
The TOOL platform uses Intel TDX (Trust Domain Extensions), which is more secure than older SGX
Privacy is achieved through hardware-based TEEs rather than cryptographic techniques like MPC or FHE
The company operates as a closed-source business competing in the MEV builder space
No public GitHub repository exists - this appears to be by design for competitive advantage
